items.title: Federal budget expected to chart a course to meet NATO's 5% spending target
items.description: What will rearming the Canadian military look like? We could get a clearer in Tuesday's federal budget. At least one defence expert says the Liberal government has made a lot of vague promises and there's a need for specifics on programs like the multi-billion dollar submarine replacement plan.

items.title: Prince Harry headed to Toronto to attend events ahead of Remembrance Day
items.description: Prince Harry will travel to Toronto this week, visiting the Sunnybrook Veterans Centre and attending a series of events in support of veterans ahead of Remembrance Day.

items.title: Ottawa urged to stop weapons flow to Sudan as Carney prepares UAE visit
items.description: Human rights groups say they believe planes meant to carry humanitarian aid from the UAE to Sudan are regularly delivering weapons instead, including possibly Canadian-made arms.

items.title: Hudson's Bay will give properties back to landlords after B.C. billionaire loses lease takeover bid
items.description: The Hudson's Bay Company is disclaiming the leases it had for 25 properties which B.C. billionaire Ruby Liu had tried to buy.

items.title: Manitoba Government's Mineral Development Fund Supports Future Mining Opportunities
Trump's tariff powers to be tested by U.S. Supreme Court. What's at stake?
items.description: The U.S. Supreme Court on Wednesday will hear arguments on whether U.S. President Donald Trump has authority to impose tariffs under emergency powers.

items.title: ‘Saves time for everybody': Saint John police launch security camera program
items.description: Saint John police are asking the public to help them strengthen surveillance around the city by registering their private security cameras.

items.title: Trump’s Coup Plans for Venezuela Are Bad News for Alberta’s Oilsands
items.description: A US-engineered regime change would flood the market with cheap, easily accessed bitumen.

items.title: Carney's immigration strategy comes during a shift in the economy — and public opinion on newcomers
Halifax housing crunch: How charities are supporting homeless as winter nears
items.description: Nova Scotia-based charities that help unhoused populations say they're seeing growing demand as the weather cools, and the housing crunch isn't helping.

items.title: Push for Richmond property tax reassessments amid uncertainty around Cowichan case
items.description: 'In fairness, I think it would be hard to argue that these properties have not had their values affected by this decision,' Paul Sullivan with Ryan Tax Firm told Global News.

items.title: Police in 2 B.C. communities warn of sewing needles in Halloween candy
items.description: Police agencies in Delta and Prince George are warning about possible Halloween candy tampering after receiving multiple reports from concerned parents.

items.title: Water From Your Eyes bring chaotic brilliance to the Biltmore Cabaret
items.description: Get the best of Vancouver in your inbox, every Tuesday and Thursday. Sign up for our free newsletter.

items.title: Remembering the Quiet Brilliance of Tom Barrett
items.description: His decades of reporting for the Vancouver Sun earned deep respect. Then he became an early pillar of The Tyee.

items.title: Child porn offenders should be buried under a prison, Manitoba premier says
Luddite Land Assembly: Weaving Sound, Storytelling and Community
items.description: Experience this immersive project and much more at the 2025 Modulus Festival in Vancouver.

items.title: TTC, Metrolinx defend transit confusion after Toronto Blue Jays loss
items.description: Toronto Transit Commission Chair Jamal Myers apologized for a social media post that urged riders to scramble to make the last subway trains while the Jays were still playing.

items.title: Fire that grew to become part of Nova Scotia’s largest wildfire started on this man’s property
items.description: Court documents from last month’s sentencing of Dalton Stewart, who was charged under the Forests Act, revealed the fire was set on land owned by Mervyn Perry. Perry says it will take years for his land to get back to what it used to be like.
